2.text: Indeed I know it is so, and that man cannot be justified compared with

3.text: If he will contend with him, he cannot answer him one for a thousand.

4.text: He is wise in heart, and mighty in strength: who hath resisted him, and hath had peace ?

5.text: Who hath removed mountains, and they whom he overthrew in his wrath, knew it not.

6.text: Who shaketh the earth out of her place, and the pillars thereof tremble.

7.text: Who commandeth tile sun and it riseth not: and shutteth up the stars as it were under a seal:

8.text: Who alone spreadeth out the heavens, and walketh upon the waves of the sea.

9.text: Who maketh Arcturus, and Orion, and Hyades, and the inner parts of the south.

10.text: Who doth things great and incomprehensible, and wonderful, of which there is no number.

11.text: If he come to me, I shall not see him: if he depart I shall not understand.

12.text: If he examine on a sudden, who shall answer him? or who can say: Why dost thou so?

13.text: God, whose wrath no man can resist, and under whom they stoop that bear up the world.

14.text: What am I then, that I should answer him, and have words with him?

15.text: I, who although I should have any just thing, would not answer, but would make supplication to my judge.

16.text: And if he should hear me when I call, I should not believe that he had heard my voice.

17.text: For he shall crush me in a whirlwind, and multiply my wounds even without cause.

18.text: He alloweth not my spirit to rest, and he filleth me with bitterness.

19.text: If strength be demanded, he is most strong: if equity of judgment, no man dare bear witness for me.

20.text: If I would justify myself, my own mouth shall condemn me: if I would shew myself innocent, he shall prove me wicked.

21.text: Although I should be simple, even this my soul shall be ignorant of, and I shall be weary of my life.

22.text: One thing there is that I have spoken, both the innocent and the wicked he consumeth.

23.text: If he scourge, let him kill at once, and not laugh at the pains of the innocent.

24.text: The earth is given into the hand of the wicked, he covereth the face of the judges thereof: and if it be not he, who is it then?

25.text: My days have been swifter than a post: they have fled away and have not seen good.

26.text: They have passed by as ships carrying fruits, as an eagle flying to the prey.

27.text: If I say: I will not speak so: I change my face, and am tormented with sorrow.

28.text: I feared all my works, knowing that thou didst not spare the offender.

29.text: But if so also I am wicked, why have I laboured in vain?

30.text: If I be washed as it were with snow waters, and my hands shall shine ever so clean :

31.text: Yet thou shalt plunge me in filth, and my garments shall abhor me,

32.text: For I shall not answer a man that is like myself: nor one that may be heard with me equally in judgment.

33.text: There is none that may be able to reprove both, and to put his hand between both.

34.text: Let him take his rod away from me, and let not his fear terrify me.

35.text: I will speak, and will not fear him: for I cannot answer while I am in fear.
